Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: The CyberPhysical Challenges of Transient Stability and Security in Power Grids

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The national transmission networks that deliver high voltage electric power underpin our society and are central to the ongoing transformation of the American energy infrastructure. Transmission networks are very large and complicated engineering systems, and "keeping the lights on" as the transformation of the American energy infrastructure proceeds is a fundamental engineering challenge involving both the physical aspects of the equipment and the cyber aspects of the controls, communications, and computers that run the system. The project develops new principles of cyber-physical engineering by focusing on instabilities of electric power networks that can cause blackouts. It proposes novel approaches to analyze these instabilities and to design cyber-physical control methods to monitor, detect, and mitigate them. The controls must perform robustly in the presence of variability and uncertainty in electric generation, loads, communications, and equipment status, and during abnormal states caused by natural faults or malicious attacks.

The research produces cyber-physical engineering methodologies that specifically help to mitigate power system blackouts and more generally show the way forward in designing robust cyber-physical systems in environments characterized by rich dynamics and uncertainty. Education and outreach efforts involve students at high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels, as well as dissemination of results to the public and the engineering and applied science communities in industry, government and universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We all depend on the high voltage transmission grid spanning the continent that supplies electrical power reliably and cheaply to our nation’s homes, businesses and government. While this transmission grid is highly reliable with only occasional cascading blackouts, these blackouts are large enough (multiple states can lose power) that they do pose an appreciable risk. At the same time, it is a matter of national security to transition the nation to sustainable electric energy that is obtained from wind, solar, nuclear and hydro power generators. In this transition the electrical grid plays a key role, and it essential to maintain its high reliability as we transition our society towards sustainability and long-term security.

The largest blackouts involve cascading in which many power grid components fail in succession in long, complicated sequences of events. These cascading events are typically very complicated because of the sustained and successful efforts by engineers to design and operate the power grid to mitigate the more obvious and likely sequences of events. That is, the straightforward blackouts have already been prevented so that when you are reading this document, it is almost certain that the lights are on. This research project developed several new ways to monitor, analyze and mitigate cascading blackouts.

The government and utilities have already invested millions of dollars in new monitoring devices called synchrophasors that can quickly and accurately track the voltages and currents flowing in the transmission grid. The project devised new ways to combine the synchrophasor measurements so that three different types of power system blackout threats could be monitored and quick actions taken as necessary to keep the grid operating. The three types of blackout threats are oscillations in which voltages across the country slowly swing up and down, a type of instability in which voltages decline until the lights go out, and multiple transmission lines overloading and automatically being removed from service. New formulations and analyses of these problems were invented to be able to use the synchrophasor measurements effectively and to be able to recommend the actions to be taken to quickly mitigate the conditions that can lead to blackout. A new course explaining synchrophasors to students was developed and taught.

All USA utilities that operate transmission grids keep records of the transmission line outages that occur. Most of the time only one or two transmission line outage, and there is no impact on customers, but occasionally there are longer cascading sequences. The project developed new ways to process this data to display the transmission line outages on the grid (see illustration) and to describe the interactions between outages. These new methods for processing real data will help power system engineers and complex network researchers understand cascading failure and improve computer simulations or mathematical models of cascading by comparing the simulated results with the real cascades.

The project supported the education of female and Hispanic graduate students in power systems engineering.
